qas.question: What day of the week does the Time for Reflection take place?
How long might a speaker address the members during the Time of Reflection?
Because speakers are drawn from across Scotland, what do the represent the balance of?
Who decides who gets to address the members of Parliament to share their thoughts on issues of faith?
What can faith groups ask the Presiding Officer to do for them?
The second item of business on Wednesdays is usually what?
What is the name for the period when members address speakers for up to four minutes?
The first item of business in the House of Lords is usually what?
Invitations to address the House of Commons are determined by whom?

context: The first item of business on <a0_0><a0_1><a0_2>Wednesdays<a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/> is usually <b5_0><b6_0>Time for Reflection<b6_0/><b5_0/>, at which a speaker addresses members for <a1_0><a1_1><a1_2>up to four minutes<a1_2/><a1_1/><a1_0/>, sharing a perspective on issues of faith. This contrasts with the formal style of "<b7_0>Prayers<b7_0/>", which is the first item of business in meetings of the House of Commons. Speakers are drawn from across Scotland and are chosen to represent <a2_2>the balance of <a2_0><a2_1>religious beliefs<a2_2/><a2_1/><a2_0/> according to the Scottish census. Invitations to address Parliament in this manner are determined by <a3_2>the <a3_0><b8_0>Presiding Officer<b8_0/><a3_2/><a3_0/> on the advice of the parliamentary bureau. Faith groups can make direct representations to the <a3_1>Presiding Officer<a3_1/> to <a4_0><a4_1><a4_2>nominate speakers<a4_2/><a4_1/><a4_0/>.
